metadata.titleEn: Surface PM2.5 concentrations in Tibetan Plateau (2021)
metadata.description: The surface PM2.5 concentration data of Tibet Plateau is named by date (YYYYMMDD). Each NC file contains one day's data, which is composed of PM2.5 concentration, longitude, latitude, and time information of the area (the corresponding variables in the data are named with PM2.5, lon, lat, time). The data inversion relies on the reanalysis data MERRA-2 released by NASA and the AOD product of Multi-angle Imaging SpectroRadiometer (MISR). MERRA-2 is mainly based on NASA GMAO Earth system model version 5 (GEOS 5). The algorithm is able to assimilate all the in-situ and re- motely-sensed atmospheric data. This dataset mainly focuses on the aerosol field of MERRA-2. This is the first multi-decadal reanalysis within which meteorological and aerosol observations are jointly assimilated into a global assimilation system. MISR views Earth with cameras pointed in 9 different directions， which can help us know the amount of sunlight that is scattered in different directions under natural conditions. The main data products used in this data algorithm are MERRA-2 aerosol analysis product (M2T1NXAER) and MISR Level 3 version 4 global aerosol products (MIL3DAEN_4). Firstly, the ratio of PM2.5 to AOD in each grid was calculated by using the aerosol information provided by MERRA-2. Second, the PM2.5 concentration of the grid was calculated by multiplying the AOD of MISR by the ratio. The mean prediction error of PM2.5 concentration obtained by this method is within 20 μg/m3. The corresponding PM2.5 products can be used for the assessment of particulate pollution in the Tibet Plateau.
metadata.instructions: In NetCDF format which can be opened with MATLAB, NCL or python.

authorList.unitEn: The Institute of Atmospheric Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences

literatureList.titleEn: Mitigating MODIS AOD non-random sampling error on surface PM2.5 estimates by a combined use of Bayesian Maximum Entropy method and linear mixed-effects model
literatureList.referenceEn: Fu, D., Song, Z., Zhang, X., Xia, X., Wang, J., Che, H., Wu, H., Tang, X., Zhang, J., & Duan, M. (2020). Mitigating MODIS AOD non-random sampling error on surface PM2.5 estimates by a combined use of Bayesian Maximum Entropy method and linear mixed-effects model. Atmos. Pollut. Res. 11, 482–490.

background: Knowledge of spatiotemporal distribution of fine particulate matter with aerodynamic diameter of 2.5μm or less (PM2.5) is highly needed since PM2.5 particles can enter the lungs, cause respiratory diseases, increase risk of cardiovascular and even lung cancer. Establishment of ground monitoring network is the ideal way to accurately measure ground-level PM 2.5 concentration, which is exactly why thousands of ground sites have been deployed in the United States and Western Europe. However, sparse geographic coverage of the network is not dense enough for monitoring PM2.5 at spatial scales of a few kilometers and maintaining such networks are very costly. It has been proved that satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD), the column-integrated aerosol extinction, is a good surrogate for PM2.5.
research objective: Here, to mitigate non-random sampling deficiency in MODIS AOD product for surface-level PM2.5 estimates, we have combined Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) method with the Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) model, for the first time, to produce more spatiotemporally complete and precise AOD products and thereafter PM2.5 estimates.
challenges: PM2.5 estimates solely based on the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) AOD products may lead to a substantial bias because of non-random AOD sampling deficiency in cloudy conditions and swap-gap regions. Furthermore, this non-random sampling issue can be exacerbated in polluted regions where heavy aerosol loadings are likely misclassified into clouds.
methods: This combined BME-LME approach was applied to MODIS and sunphotometer AOD products over the North China Plain.
dataset: Ground-based AOD measurements from Sun-photometers (Cimel Electronique, CE-318) were collected at 9 stations as a part of CARSNET or AERONET in NCP (Fig. 1). The latest Version 3 cloud-screened and quality assured AOD data (Level 2.0) are used for calculating daily mean AOD. Hourly PM2.5 concentrations from September 2014 to February 2015 at 264 monitors (Fig. 1) are obtained from the website of the China Environmental Monitoring Center (CEMC) (http://106.37.208.233:20035/).
findings: Relative to the standard MODIS AOD product, the integration of MODIS and sunphotometer AOD through BME showed increases in both spatiotemporal completeness (up to 96%) and the quality. The resultant monthly PM2.5 estimates from the BME-LME had a bias of 3.5 μgm −3 and a root mean square error (RMSE) of 5.5μgm −3, showing substantial improvement over PM2.5 estimations from original MODIS AOD product (a bias of 84.1 and a RMSE of 112.1μgm −3). Merging sunphotometer and satellite AOD observations with BME-LME is a prospective method to simultaneously improve AOD and PM2.5 estimates.

Verification.Question: Is the integration of different AOD data sources a viable method to improve PM2.5 estimates?

Disjunctive.Question: Which satellite product is more commonly used for estimating surface-level PM2.5 concentrations, MODIS AOD or MISR AOD?

Concept Completion.Question: What is the primary method used to calculate PM2.5 concentrations on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Who provides the data products used in calculating PM2.5 concentrations for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that combines satellite data with ground-based measurements to improve air quality monitoring?
Example.Answer: An example of such a method is the combination of Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) with the Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) model, which integrates MODIS and sunphotometer AOD products for more complete and precise PM2.5 estimates.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered when using satellite data for PM2.5 estimation?
Example.Answer: A challenge in using satellite data like the MODIS AOD products for PM2.5 estimates is the non-random AOD sampling deficiency in cloudy conditions and swap-gap regions, which can lead to substantial biases, especially in polluted areas where high aerosol loadings may be misclassified as clouds.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key features of data collection methods for PM2.5 concentration in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: NASA's MERRA-2 reanalysis data, MISR AOD products, aerosol information integration, PM2.5 to AOD ratios, MISR's AOD estimation

Feature Specification.Question: What attributes of datasets are crucial for improving PM2.5 estimates through combined methodologies?
Feature Specification.Answer: integration of satellite AOD products with ground-based AOD measurements, spatiotemporal completeness, quality, reduced bias, reduced RMSE

Quantification.Question: What is the bias in micrograms per cubic meter of the monthly PM2.5 estimates when using the integrated BME-LME method compared to the original MODIS AOD product?

Definition.Question: What does 'non-random AOD sampling deficiency' mean in air quality estimation?
Definition.Answer: Non-random AOD sampling deficiency refers to the issue where AOD measurements are incomplete due to cloud cover or swap-gap regions, which can lead to a substantial bias in PM2.5 estimates, especially in polluted regions where heavy aerosol loadings might be misclassified as clouds.

Definition.Question: How does the integration of MODIS and sunphotometer AOD data improve PM2.5 estimates?
Definition.Answer: The integration using the Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) method with the Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) model increases spatiotemporal completeness and quality of the AOD data, reducing bias and root mean square error in PM2.5 estimates compared to using the standard MODIS AOD product alone.

Comparison.Question: How does the accuracy of PM2.5 concentration estimates derived from NASA's MERRA-2 and MISR data compare to estimates derived using the combined Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) and Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) model with MODIS AOD products?
Comparison.Answer: PM2.5 concentration estimates derived from NASA's MERRA-2 and MISR data rely on calculating the PM2.5 to AOD ratio using aerosol information, achieving an average prediction error within 20 micrograms per cubic meter. The combined BME-LME model using MODIS AOD products showed a significant improvement with a bias of 3.5 μgm−3 and RMSE of 5.5 μgm−3, compared to the original MODIS AOD product.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying rules or strategies can be inferred about data collection methods that integrate satellite-based aerosol optical depth data with ground-level PM2.5 measurements?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) data with ground-level PM2.5 measurements can infer a strategy of using AOD as a surrogate for PM2.5 due to the challenge of sparse geographic coverage of ground monitoring networks. This method can help improve spatial and temporal completeness by combining satellite AOD products with ground-based observations and applying statistical models, such as the Bayesian maximum entropy and Linear Mixed-Effects models, to address biases and non-random sampling issues.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in data collection can be interpreted from the non-random sampling deficiencies in satellite AOD products for PM2.5 estimation?
Interpretation.Answer: The non-random sampling deficiencies in satellite AOD products present challenges such as substantial bias in PM2.5 estimates, especially in cloudy conditions and swap-gap regions. These challenges are exacerbated in regions with heavy aerosol loadings, which may be misclassified into clouds. Addressing these issues requires the development of methodologies that can integrate both satellite and ground-based data to improve the accuracy and coverage of PM2.5 estimates.

Interpretation.Question: How can the use of algorithmic approaches be interpreted in the context of improving the data quality and coverage of PM2.5 concentration estimates?
Interpretation.Answer: Algorithmic approaches, such as combining different data sources and applying advanced statistical models, can significantly improve the quality and coverage of PM2.5 concentration estimates. By utilizing algorithms that incorporate both MERRA-2 aerosol data and MISR AOD products, researchers can better estimate PM2.5 concentrations with reduced prediction errors. This suggests the importance of integrating multiple data sources and computational models to enhance the robustness and reliability of air quality assessments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the limitations in geographic coverage for ground monitoring networks when assessing PM2.5 concentrations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The sparse geographic coverage of ground monitoring networks is primarily due to the high cost of maintaining such networks, which prevents them from being dense enough to monitor PM2.5 at spatial scales of a few kilometers.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might satellite-based AOD be used as a surrogate for PM2.5 measurements?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) is used as a surrogate for PM2.5 because it represents the column-integrated aerosol extinction, which can provide a proxy measurement for ground-level PM2.5 concentrations, especially when ground network coverage is insufficient.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What leads to biases in PM2.5 estimates from MODIS AOD products?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Biases in PM2.5 estimates from MODIS AOD products are caused by non-random AOD sampling deficiency, especially in cloudy conditions and swap-gap regions, which can be exacerbated in polluted regions where heavy aerosol loadings are misclassified as clouds.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the likely outcomes of integrating both ground-based and satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) data in estimating surface-level PM2.5 concentrations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating both ground-based and satellite-based AOD data can significantly enhance the spatiotemporal completeness and quality of PM2.5 estimates, reducing bias and root mean square error (RMSE) compared to using satellite data alone.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does relying solely on satellite AOD products impact the accuracy of PM2.5 estimates, particularly in polluted regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Relying solely on satellite AOD products may introduce substantial bias in PM2.5 estimates due to non-random AOD sampling deficiencies in cloudy conditions and swap-gap regions, especially in polluted areas where heavy aerosol loadings can be misclassified as clouds.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intended outcome of using satellite observations like MERRA-2 and MISR for calculating PM2.5 concentrations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcome is to provide a reference for assessing particulate matter pollution in regions like the Tibetan Plateau by integrating meteorological and aerosol data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) be utilized to improve the estimation of ground-level PM2.5 concentrations in regions with sparse monitoring networks?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD), such as that from NASA's MERRA-2 and MISR products, can be used as a surrogate for PM2.5 by calculating the PM2.5 to AOD ratio at each grid point. This approach, as applied in the field, involves using MERRA-2's aerosol analysis products to calculate the PM2.5/AOD ratio and then multiplying it by MISR's AOD values to estimate PM2.5 concentrations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key procedural steps involved in combining Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) and Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) models to enhance PM2.5 estimates from MODIS AOD data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The combination of BME and LME models involves integrating MODIS and sunphotometer AOD data to address non-random sampling deficiencies. This approach enhances spatiotemporal completeness and accuracy by merging satellite and ground-based AOD observations, resulting in improved PM2.5 estimates with reduced bias and root mean square error compared to standard MODIS AOD products.

Enablement.Question: How does combining Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) with the Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) model enable more accurate PM2.5 estimates from satellite data?
Enablement.Answer: Combining Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) with the Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) model enables more accurate PM2.5 estimates by addressing non-random sampling deficiencies in MODIS AOD products, thus producing more spatiotemporally complete and precise AOD products for PM2.5 estimation.

Enablement.Question: What datasets and conditions are necessary to accurately calculate the PM2.5 to AOD ratio for improving PM2.5 concentration predictions using satellite data?
Enablement.Answer: Accurate calculation of the PM2.5 to AOD ratio for improving PM2.5 concentration predictions requires datasets such as MERRA-2 aerosol analysis products and MISR level 3 global aerosol products, alongside conditions that allow for the integration of aerosol information from MERRA-2 and AOD data from MISR.

Expectation.Question: Why might satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) be considered a good surrogate for PM2.5 in data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: Satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) is considered a good surrogate for PM2.5 because AOD represents the column-integrated aerosol extinction, which can be used to estimate surface-level PM2.5 concentrations. This is particularly useful in areas where ground monitoring networks are sparse or costly to maintain.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise from relying solely on Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) AOD products for PM2.5 estimates?
Expectation.Answer: Relying solely on MODIS AOD products for PM2.5 estimates can lead to substantial bias due to non-random AOD sampling deficiencies in cloudy conditions and in regions with swap gaps. This issue can be further exacerbated in polluted areas where heavy aerosol loadings may be misclassified as clouds.

Expectation.Question: Why is it necessary to combine Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) with Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) models for improving PM2.5 estimates?
Expectation.Answer: Combining BME with LME models is necessary for improving PM2.5 estimates as it addresses the non-random sampling deficiency in MODIS AOD products, producing more spatiotemporally complete and precise AOD products and thereby yielding more accurate PM2.5 estimates.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of combining satellite-based aerosol optical depth with ground-based measurements in improving PM2.5 concentration estimations?
Judgmental.Answer: The combination of satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) with ground-based measurements is considered effective in improving PM2.5 concentration estimations. The integration of MODIS and sunphotometer AOD through the BME-LME approach significantly enhanced spatiotemporal completeness and quality, reducing bias and root mean square error compared to using MODIS AOD alone.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in using satellite-derived data for estimating ground-level PM2.5 concentrations, and how might these be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: One potential challenge in using satellite-derived data for estimating ground-level PM2.5 concentrations is the non-random AOD sampling deficiency in cloudy conditions and regions with heavy aerosol loadings, which can be misclassified as clouds. This challenge could be addressed by combining satellite AOD data with ground-based measurements and applying advanced statistical models like BME-LME to produce more complete and precise estimates.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the integration of different satellite and ground-based data sources can improve the accuracy of PM2.5 concentration estimates.
Assertion.Answer: The integration of satellite-based aerosol optical depth (AOD) products with ground-based measurements can enhance the accuracy of PM2.5 estimates by providing more spatiotemporally complete data. Combining datasets like MODIS AOD with sunphotometer AOD through advanced methods such as Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) and Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) models can address non-random sampling deficiencies and improve both the completeness and quality of the estimates.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges in the data collection process for aerosol measurements and how they might affect PM2.5 estimation.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in aerosol data collection include non-random sampling deficiencies, particularly in cloudy conditions and regions with heavy aerosol loadings, which may be misclassified as clouds. Such issues can lead to substantial biases in PM2.5 estimates if based solely on certain AOD products like those from MODIS. By addressing these challenges through the integration of multiple data sources and advanced statistical methods, more accurate PM2.5 estimates can be achieved.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand what types of datasets are typically used to evaluate and improve PM2.5 estimation methods.
Assertion.Answer: To evaluate and improve PM2.5 estimation methods, datasets such as ground-based AOD measurements from sun-photometers and hourly PM2.5 concentrations from environmental monitoring centers are used. These datasets allow for the calibration and validation of satellite-based products, ensuring that the derived PM2.5 estimates are both accurate and reliable.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and discuss the data collection methods used to mitigate non-random sampling deficiencies in AOD products for PM2.5 estimation.
Request/Directive.Answer: To mitigate non-random sampling deficiencies in AOD products, a combination of Bayesian maximum entropy (BME) method with Linear Mixed-Effects (LME) model is used. This approach, when applied to MODIS and sunphotometer AOD products, has been shown to produce more spatiotemporally complete and precise AOD products, thereby improving PM2.5 estimates.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the potential datasets that could be integrated to improve the accuracy and completeness of PM2.5 concentration estimates at a regional scale.
Request/Directive.Answer: Ground-based AOD measurements from sun-photometers, such as those collected as part of CARSNET or AERONET, can be integrated with satellite data like MODIS AOD products. The BME-LME approach has demonstrated that merging these datasets can significantly enhance the spatiotemporal completeness and quality of PM2.5 estimates.
